channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Turkey’s Unrest, Some See an Extreme Version of Post-9/11 America
item.media:description: Police officers in Istanbul, near a nightclub where New Year’s revelers were killed. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has responded to violence and a coup attempt with a furious crackdown.
item.description: Turkey’s president and his allies say no other democracy has withstood such relentless terrorist attacks and a coup attempt.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Jill Saward, Advocate for Victims of Sexual Assault, Dies at 51
item.media:description: Jill Saward in 2006.
item.description: Ms. Saward was a British survivor of rape who waived her right to anonymity and called on other victims to come forward to share their ordeal.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Greece’s Most-Wanted Terrorist, on Run Since 2012, Is Arrested and Charged
item.media:description: Panagiota Roupa, a leader of the anarchist group Revolutionary Struggle, being escorted by antiterrorist police officers in Athens on Thursday. The group carried out bombings and shootings targeting the police and others starting in 2003.
item.description: Panagiota Roupa was the leader of Revolutionary Struggle, which was involved in a string of attacks, including one on the United States Embassy in Athens.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: In Zimbabwe, a First Lady Exerts Her Power
item.media:description: Grace Mugabe at the opening of the Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front’s annual congress last month in Masvingo, Zimbabwe.
item.description: Grace Mugabe, the wife of President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, is one of the main actors maneuvering to succeed him.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Soldiers Mutiny in Ivory Coast, Reviving Memories of Civil War
item.media:description: United Nations peacekeepers arrived Friday at Bouaké, Ivory Coast, where earlier in the day soldiers demanding more pay had closed roads into the city.
item.description: Demanding pay raises and other benefits, soldiers took up arms in at least two cities in the West African nation, paralyzing commerce and terrifying residents.
item.dc:creator: SEAN LYNGAAS and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: No Charges in Sexual Abuse Case Involving French Peacekeepers
item.description: A confidential 2014 U.N. report had implicated soldiers in the abuse of children in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations

item.title: Opposition: At Least 43 Killed in Car Bomb in Syrian Town
item.description: At least 43 people were killed Saturday when a car bomb went off in a busy market in a rebel-held Syrian town along the Turkish border, activists and rescue workers said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russian Aircraft Carrier Is Called Back as Part of Syrian Drawdown
item.media:description: The Russian aircraft carrier Admiral Kuznetsov has been called back to its home port, Murmansk.
item.media:credit: Norway Royal Airforce, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: A senior general ordered the country’s only carrier to return home from the Mediterranean as Russia begins to pull its armed forces from the war in Syria.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Jared Kushner, a Trump In-Law and Adviser, Chases a Chinese Deal
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump officially announced his campaign for the presidency at Trump Tower in Manhattan on June 16, 2015, with his daughter Ivanka and her husband, Jared Kushner, at his side.
item.description: As Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law prepares for a White House role, his undisclosed talks with a secretive Chinese company highlight potential conflicts of interest.
item.dc:creator: SUSANNE CRAIG, JO BECKER and JESSE DRUCKER

item.title: ‘I Thought I Was Impervious to Scams’: Readers Denounce India’s Phone Swindlers
item.media:description: Pawan Poojary, 18, left, and Jayesh Dubey, 19, worked at a call center in Thane, a suburb of Mumbai, India, that targeted Americans.
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.description: Many responding to a Times article about a call center voiced sympathy for the victims of fraud, and anger at the criminals and a system that does little to protect the vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Voice of Brazilian Rodeo Rides a National Movement to the Right
item.media:description: A family secured first-row seats for a rodeo appearance by Cuiabanno Lima last month in Goiânia, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: As agribusiness has grown, rodeo has surged in popularity. A leading announcer follows the buckaroos, and speaks to Brazil’s shifting politics.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Dozens of Inmates Killed as Prison Violence Escalates in Brazil
item.media:description: Freshly dug graves for inmates who died during a prison riot, at the cemetery of Taruma in Manaus, Brazil, on Wednesday.
item.description: The deaths of at least 31 prisoners, coming days after a massacre at a jail in the city of Manaus, adds to fears about an intensifying war between drug gangs.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: What in the World: To Fight Smog, How About Rooftop Bus Gardens?
item.description: A contest in India taps the homegrown art of jugaad — making use of whatever is available — for solutions to Delhi’s oppressive air pollution.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Canada Today: 150 Years Ago, the No. 1 Destination and Lots of Hockey
item.media:description: The Centennial Flame, on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, was built to commemorate Canada’s 100th anniversary in 1967.
item.media:credit: David Giral for The New York Times
item.description: Examinations of the country’s founding, its attraction to tourists and some of its many tales of icy competition.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Kerry Lists Obama Era’s Diplomatic Successes. (Trump Opposes Them All.)
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry wrote an exit memo enumerating the Obama administration’s foreign policy accomplishments.
item.description: In a memo summing up the last eight years of foreign policy, the secretary of state enumerated and defended the Obama administration’s work.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: 4 Men Held in Bangalore in New Year’s Eve Attack Caught on Video
item.media:description: Protesters gathered in Bangalore, India, on Thursday to demand justice after reports of men molesting women in the city on New Year’s Eve.
item.description: The assault, captured on a security video, occurred in an area away from one where crowds of men were said to have molested women the same night, police said.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Czech Artist’s Grandson Sues to Block Loan of Works to Tokyo
item.media:description: An installation view of Alphonse Mucha‘s “Slav Epic,” a cycle of 20 large canvases shown since 2012 at the Veletrzni Palace, part of the National Gallery in Prague.
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.description: John Mucha not only wants to stop Prague City Gallery from shipping Alphonse Mucha’s “Slav Epic” to Japan, he wants the paintings to revert to the Mucha estate.
item.dc:creator: PHILIP J. HEIJMANS

item.title: Gunmen Attack Hazara Miners in Afghanistan, Killing at Least 9
item.description: The shooting, which some officials say left as many as 13 people dead, seemingly adds to a string of attacks singling out ethnic or sectarian minorities.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: The Saturday Profile: He Helped Topple a Dictator. In New York, He’s Another Face in the Crowd.
item.media:description: Souleymane Guengueng, who was one of numerous people imprisoned and tortured during the brutal reign of President Hissène Habré in Chad, now lives in a public housing complex in the Bronx.
item.description: Souleymane Guengueng was tortured and imprisoned in Chad. He has experienced financial troubles and bad luck in the Bronx. But he is not giving up.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Chinese Defy Pollution, a Stubborn Visitor
item.media:description: Dancing at a park blanketed by severe smog in Fuyang, China, on Tuesday.
item.description: For many, living in a wintertime miasma has become a routine to be endured, even flouted with an outdoor fox trot.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Bangladeshi Suspected of Training Militants in Dhaka Bakery Attack Is Killed
item.media:description: A police checkpoint near the Holey Artisan Bakery in Dhaka, Bangladesh, after the terrorist attack in July that left 22 people dead.
item.description: Nurul Islam Marzan, who was killed by the police in a gunfight, helped guide a team of attackers through the deadly siege last year, officials say.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sinosphere: How the Qing Court Sowed the Seeds of Environmental Protection in China
item.media:description: A Chinese tourist posing for a photograph at Changbaishan, on the Chinese-North Korean border. The Manchus who ruled China during the Qing dynasty considered the area to be their ancestral homeland and protected it from overexploitation by hunters and foragers.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Jonathan Schlesinger, the author of “A World Trimmed With Fur,” discusses the Qing dynasty’s resource management and its influence on conservation in modern China.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Japan Recalls Ambassador to South Korea to Protest ‘Comfort Woman’ Statue
item.media:description: A statue of a girl representing the Korean women forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese military being unveiled during a rally in front of the Japanese Consulate in Busan, South Korea, last week.
item.description: The statue, commemorating Korean women forced into sexual slavery during World War II, was installed by activists last week near Japan’s consulate in the city of Busan.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and MOTOKO RICH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Indonesia Backs Off Plan to Suspend Ties With Australia’s Military
item.media:description: Gen. Gatot Nurmantyo, in white hat, and President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, foreground right, in Jakarta in December. The suspension of military ties with Australia by General Gatot threatened Indonesia’s efforts to improve relations with its neighbor.
item.media:credit: Agus Suparto/Indonesian Presidency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The flare-up, over training material deemed insulting to Indonesians, threatened a key military alliance and raised questions about internal Indonesian politics.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY HUTTON

item.title: Sinosphere: A Poem Praises Smog, and Why Not? It’s From Cancer’s Perspective
item.media:description: A farmer walking through heavy smog on the outskirts of Beijing on Saturday.
item.description: China’s toxic air has drawn attention to a Chinese surgeon’s poem that takes the viewpoint of a hungry lung cancer reveling in the “delicious mist and haze.”
item.dc:creator: KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Editorial: No Closure on the ‘Comfort Women’
item.media:description: A statue of a girl representing Korean “comfort women” outside the Japanese consulate in Busan, South Korea.
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.description: Despite a formal agreement with Japan, many Koreans still do not feel Japan has truly acknowledged its past crimes.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Editorial: An Exit Plan for Congo’s Kabila
item.media:description: Congolese bishops arriving for talks between the Kabila government and the opposition.
item.description: Holed up in his Kinshasa mansion, the president is still trying to wait out his enemies.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
